definitions.definition: a supply of goods that is available for sale in a shop
definitions.sensetop: in stockout of stockstock of something
definitions.labels: (especially British English)(especially North American English)(especially North American English)(British English)(especially North American English)(North American English, informal)(British English)(North American English)(British English)(British English)(North American English)(British English)(North American English)(British English)(North American English)(North American English)(British English)(especially North American English)(especially British English)(British English)(North American English)

examples.text: We have a fast turnover of stock.
That particular model is not currently in stock.
I'm afraid we're temporarily out of stock.
We don't carry a large stock of pine furniture.
It is important to carry out regular stock checks.
Do you have futon beds in stock or will I have to order one?
Red tights are out of stock.
The offer is only available while stocks last.
We can supply the table from stock.
They're selling off their old stock cheap.
They're getting rid of their old stock.
The big supermarkets carry huge stocks of most goods.

definitions.definition: a supply of something that is available for use

examples.text: Food stocks are running low.
declining **fish stocks** in the oceans
a country’s **housing stock** *(= all the houses available for living in)*
She's built up a good stock of teaching materials over the years.
laws to protect fish stocks
dwindling fish stocks in the North Sea
Stocks of coal are running dangerously low.
The housing stock is no longer large enough for the population.

definitions.definition: the value of the shares in a company that have been sold

examples.text: The company's stock hit an all-time high of $94.66.

definitions.definition: a share that somebody has bought in a company or business

examples.text: **stock prices**
to **buy/sell/trade stocks**
to invest in **stocks and shares**
to invest in **stocks and bonds**
The stocks were valued at $100 000.
The total value of the stocks was over $3 million.
She has about $30 000 in stocks.

definitions.definition: money that is lent to a government at a fixed rate of interest; an official document that gives details of this

examples.text: government stock

definitions.definition: farm animals, such as cows and sheep, that are kept for their meat, wool, etc.

examples.text: breeding stock

definitions.definition: having the type of family or ancestors mentioned
definitions.sensetop: of farming, noble, French, etc. stock

definitions.definition: a liquid made by cooking bones, meat, etc. in water, used for making soups and sauces

examples.text: vegetable stock
You can flavour the stock with bay leaves.
Poach the fish in the stock.

definitions.definition: a wooden structure with holes for the feet, used in the past to lock criminals in as a form of punishment, especially in a public place
the degree to which somebody is respected or liked by other people

examples.text: Their **stock is high/low**.

definitions.definition: the part of a gun that you hold against your shoulder when firing it
a garden plant with brightly coloured flowers with a sweet smell
a theatre company that does several different plays in a season; a repertory company

examples.text: He sold the business lock, stock and barrel.

definitions.definition: in the process of being made, built or prepared

examples.text: Our new model is already on the stocks and will be available in the spring.

definitions.definition: to have a particular amount of belief in something

examples.text: She no longer puts much stock in their claims.

definitions.definition: to stop and think carefully about the way in which a particular situation is developing in order to decide what to do next

examples.text: It was time to stand back and take stock of his career.

wordOrigin: Old English stoc(c) ‘trunk, block of wood, post’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch stok and German Stock ‘stick’. The notion ‘store, fund’ (senses (1) to (5)) arose in late Middle English and is of obscure origin, perhaps expressing “growth from a central stem” or “firm foundation”.
